title: Bar Glassware Handling
legalBasis: Ley 31/1995 de Prevención de Riesgos Laborales (Spanish Occupational Health and Safety Law); RD 486/1997 on workplace safety requirements; general duty of care under Spanish tort law
summary:
Broken glass represents one of the most common and preventable hazards in bar and restaurant environments. Glass injuries can range from minor cuts to serious lacerations requiring medical attention, and improper disposal of broken glass creates ongoing risks for all staff. Every bar worker handles hundreds of glasses per shift, creating multiple opportunities for accidents if proper handling techniques are not followed.

This guide establishes comprehensive procedures for the safe handling, inspection, storage, and disposal of glassware in hospitality settings. It covers selection of appropriate glassware, pre-service inspection protocols, safe carrying and serving techniques, immediate response to breakage, and proper cleanup and disposal procedures. These protocols not only protect staff from injury but also ensure customer safety and maintain hygiene standards.

Implementing these procedures requires initial training for all bar staff, provision of appropriate tools (such as dustpans with soft brushes for glass pickup), and establishment of a safety culture where taking time to handle glass properly is valued over speed. Regular reinforcement through toolbox talks and incident reviews helps maintain compliance.
keyPoints: Inspect all glassware before use — discard any chipped, cracked, or damaged items immediately
Never pick up broken glass with bare hands under any circumstances
Use a stiff brush and dustpan, damp cloth, or vacuum for broken glass cleanup
Maintain a separate, clearly labeled container for broken glass disposal
Never use glass to scoop ice — this creates invisible glass fragments in the ice bin
Handle glasses by the stem or base, never by inserting fingers into the rim
Stack glasses carefully according to their design — not all glassware is stackable
Keep hands visible when carrying glasses to avoid collisions with customers or colleagues
Report all glass-related injuries immediately, no matter how minor they appear
Conduct a thorough sweep of the area after any glass breakage to remove all fragments

sections.heading: 1. Glassware Selection and Pre-Service Inspection
sections.content:
The foundation of glass safety begins before service starts, with proper selection of appropriate glassware for the establishment's needs and systematic inspection to identify damaged items before they reach customers. Tempered glassware, which shatters into small, less dangerous fragments rather than large shards, should be specified for high-volume areas where breakage risk is elevated. However, even tempered glass must be inspected and handled properly.

Every piece of glassware should pass through visual and tactile inspection before being placed into service. Hold each glass up to light to check for cracks, which may not be visible in dimmer light. Run your finger around the rim to detect chips that could cut a customer's lip. Check the base and stem (if applicable) for stress fractures. This inspection takes only seconds per glass and prevents both customer injuries and the risk of breakage during service.

Establish a clear protocol for removing damaged glassware from circulation. Damaged items should never be returned to service 'just this once' during a busy period. The immediate cost of discarding a damaged glass is trivial compared to the potential cost of a customer injury or staff laceration. Create a designated area for rejected glassware that prevents it from being accidentally reused.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Damage Detection Techniques
subsections.content:
Visual inspection under good lighting is the first line of defense. Look for obvious chips, cracks, and clouding that indicates stress in the glass structure. Rim chips are particularly dangerous for customers. Star cracks in the base can cause sudden breakage when the glass is set down on a hard surface.

The finger-rim test is essential: gently run your fingertip completely around the rim. Even tiny chips that are difficult to see can be felt as a rough spot that catches on your skin. For stemware, pay particular attention to the join between bowl and stem, as this is a common stress point. The ping test — tapping the glass gently with a fingernail — produces a clear ring in undamaged glass but a dull thud in cracked glass, though this requires experience to interpret accurately.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Quality Standards for Glassware Purchase
subsections.content:
When specifying glassware for purchase, prioritize safety alongside aesthetics and cost. Request certification that glassware meets relevant safety standards such as EN 1811 or ISO 7086 for stemware. Tempered glass should meet EN 12750 or equivalent standards. Verify that the supplier can provide replacement stock for your chosen patterns to avoid mixing incompatible glassware.

Consider the operational environment when selecting glass thickness and design. High-volume bars serving large volumes of beer may benefit from thicker-walled glasses that withstand frequent handling. Wine bars may prioritize thinner, more elegant stemware but must accept higher breakage rates and implement correspondingly stricter handling protocols. The right choice balances customer experience, staff safety, and operational efficiency.

sections.heading: 2. Safe Handling Techniques During Service
sections.content:
Proper handling techniques significantly reduce glass breakage and the associated injury risks. The primary principle is to minimize stress on the glass and to handle it in ways that provide secure grip without creating leverage that could cause breakage. Different glass types require different techniques, but certain principles apply universally.

For stemware, always hold by the stem or base, never by the bowl. Holding the bowl applies heat from your hand that can weaken the glass over time, leaves fingerprints that are unprofessional, and provides less secure grip. When carrying multiple stem glasses, use a tray rather than carrying them between your fingers, as this risks both dropping and glass-on-glass collision. If you must carry glasses without a tray, carry them by the base in a stable grouping.

For tumbler-style glasses (highballs, rocks glasses, pint glasses), grasp firmly around the lower third of the glass, not the rim. Never stack glasses unless they are specifically designed for stacking. Forcing non-stackable glasses together creates stress that causes cracking, and the glasses may stick together requiring excessive force to separate. When in doubt, carry glasses individually or use a tray.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Washing and Drying Procedures
subsections.content:
Manual washing requires particular care as wet glass is both slippery and more fragile due to micro-abrasions caused by the washing process. Use a circular motion rather than twisting, which creates torque stress on the glass. Never force glasses over brush heads or faucets in the sink. Stemware should be washed by holding the base, never twisting the bowl against the stem as this is a common cause of stem breakage.

When drying glasses, use lint-free cloths and again avoid twisting motions. For stemware, hold the base firmly with one hand and gently polish the bowl with the cloth in the other hand. Never insert the cloth deeply into the glass and twist, as this creates leverage that can break the glass, potentially driving shards into your hand. Allow glasses to air-dry when time permits, as this eliminates handling during the vulnerable drying process.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Service and Customer Interaction
subsections.content:
When serving drinks, place the glass on the table or bar — do not hand it directly to the customer unless they specifically reach for it. This prevents accidental drops and collisions. Announce your presence when approaching from behind to avoid startling customers who might knock the glass from your hand. Clear finished glasses from the table by grasping the base, checking first that the glass is truly empty to avoid spilling residual liquid.

Be aware of the risk of glass-to-glass collision during busy service. Maintain visual awareness of your surroundings and other staff members carrying glassware. Call out 'behind' or 'glasses' when passing behind colleagues with glassware. Never rush when carrying glasses — speed-related accidents are a primary cause of breakage and injury in bar environments.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Ice Service Protocols
subsections.content:
The practice of using a glass to scoop ice is extremely dangerous and must be absolutely prohibited. When glass breaks inside an ice bin, it is virtually impossible to remove all fragments. Invisible glass shards then contaminate every drink served from that ice bin, creating a serious customer safety hazard. The only acceptable ice scooping tools are dedicated metal or plastic scoops with handles.

If a glass does break in or near an ice bin, the entire bin must be emptied, the ice discarded, and the bin thoroughly cleaned and inspected before refilling. This is time-consuming and costly, but there is no acceptable alternative. Some establishments keep ice bins covered when not in use to prevent accidental glass breakage into the ice.

sections.heading: 3. Broken Glass Response Procedures
sections.content:
Despite all preventive measures, glass will occasionally break in any bar environment. The immediate response to breakage determines whether this becomes a minor inconvenience or a serious safety incident. The first priority is always to secure the area to prevent injury to staff and customers. The second is to ensure complete cleanup so that no glass fragments remain to cause later injuries.

When glass breaks, immediately call out 'broken glass' or 'glass' in a clear voice to alert everyone in the area. If the breakage occurred in a customer area, politely but firmly ask customers to step back from the immediate area. If anyone is injured, address the injury immediately before beginning cleanup. Even small cuts from glass can become infected and should be cleaned and covered with a waterproof plaster.

Do not begin cleanup until you have assembled the proper tools. Attempting to pick up glass fragments with bare hands, even large pieces that appear safe to handle, is the most common cause of glass cuts in hospitality. The proper cleanup toolkit includes: a stiff-bristled brush or dustpan brush, a dustpan, damp paper towels or disposable cloths for collecting small fragments, and access to the broken glass disposal container.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Immediate Area Management
subsections.content:
Mark the area clearly if it cannot be cleaned immediately. Use a chair, cone, or other visible barrier to prevent people from walking through the area. In low-light environments such as bars and clubs, broken glass may be invisible on dark floors, so physical barriers are essential. Assign a staff member to monitor the area if it must remain uncleaned for any period.

If glass has broken near food preparation or service areas, inspect the immediate surroundings for glass fragments that may have scattered. Glass can travel surprising distances when it shatters, particularly if it breaks on a hard surface. Check surrounding counters, shelving, and even food items that may have been contaminated by flying glass fragments. When in doubt, discard food items that may have been exposed.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Cleanup Methodology
subsections.content:
Begin with large fragments, using the dustpan or a piece of stiff cardboard to maneuver them into the dustpan without direct hand contact. Progress to smaller fragments using the brush. For the smallest fragments and glass dust, use damp paper towels or cloths — the moisture captures the tiny fragments that a dry brush might scatter. Work methodically from the outer edges of the breakage area toward the center to avoid spreading fragments.

Once the visible glass is removed, wipe the area again with a fresh damp cloth to capture any remaining dust-sized particles. In carpeted areas, use a vacuum cleaner with a hose attachment, but be aware that some glass fragments may be too fine for the vacuum to capture. After vacuuming, carefully blot the area with damp cloths as a final check. Hard floors should be mopped after sweeping to ensure complete removal of glass dust.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Disposal and Final Verification
subsections.content:
Broken glass must be disposed of in a separate, clearly marked container — never in general waste bins where it could injure cleaning staff or waste handlers. Ideally, use a puncture-resistant container such as a designated broken glass box or a thick cardboard box clearly labeled 'BROKEN GLASS — HANDLE WITH CARE'. When the container is full, seal it securely before disposal.

Before declaring cleanup complete, inspect the area in good light from multiple angles. Glass fragments can be difficult to see against certain floor colors and textures. Run a damp cloth over the area one final time and inspect the cloth for any glass particles. Consider making an announcement to alert all staff that glass was broken in a specific location, so everyone remains alert for any missed fragments during the remainder of the shift.

sections.heading: 4. Storage and Stock Management
sections.content:
Proper storage of glassware reduces handling, minimizes breakage, and maintains hygiene. Storage areas should be organized logically with frequently used items easily accessible to avoid excessive reaching and moving of stock. Shelving should be at appropriate heights — approximately waist to shoulder height for daily-use items — to minimize the risk of dropping glasses when retrieving or storing them.

Glasses should be stored upright on clean, dry shelving. The traditional practice of storing glasses inverted (upside down) on bar mats is now discouraged by food safety authorities as it prevents air circulation and can trap odors and contaminants. If glasses must be stored inverted, ensure the storage surface is scrupulously clean and allow glasses to dry fully before inverting. Never store glasses inverted on surfaces where spills or splashes might occur.

Organize storage by glass type to prevent the need to move multiple items to access the one required. Keep backup stock in a separate, secure area to reduce clutter in the working bar environment. Conduct regular inventory of glassware to identify breakage patterns and reorder before stock becomes critically low, which can lead to rushed handling and increased breakage.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Environmental Factors
subsections.content:
Glass storage areas should be stable and level to prevent glasses from sliding or tipping. Avoid storing glassware near heat sources such as dishwashers or ovens, as repeated thermal stress weakens glass over time. Ensure that storage shelving is adequately rated for the weight of glassware — glass is deceptively heavy in quantity, and overloaded shelves can collapse.

Protect stored glassware from contamination by dust, insects, and chemical exposure. In environments where cleaning is conducted with spray chemicals, cover glassware or store it in closed cabinets during cleaning operations. Glass readily absorbs odors, so storage areas should be well-ventilated and away from strong-smelling substances.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Rotation and Lifecycle Management
subsections.content:
Implement a first-in, first-out rotation system for glassware to ensure even wear across your inventory. Glasses that sit unused for extended periods may develop clouding or contamination. Regular use and washing actually extends glass life by preventing buildup of residues that can weaken the glass structure.

Establish a replacement schedule based on usage patterns. High-volume establishments may need to replace a proportion of glassware every 6-12 months due to cumulative micro-damage from washing and handling. Track breakage rates by location and time to identify whether certain service areas, shifts, or staff members experience higher breakage. This data helps target training and procedural improvements effectively.

sections.heading: 5. Training and Safety Culture
sections.content:
Technical procedures alone do not ensure glass safety — they must be embedded in a broader safety culture where every team member understands their personal responsibility and feels empowered to prioritize safety over speed. This requires leadership commitment, regular training, open communication about incidents and near-misses, and recognition of good safety practices.

All new bar staff should receive comprehensive glassware safety training during induction, with both theoretical instruction and practical demonstration. This training should cover all the procedures outlined in this guide, with emphasis on the two most critical rules: never pick up broken glass with bare hands, and never use glasses to scoop ice. Provide opportunities for questions and practice under supervision.

Refresher training should be provided at least annually for all staff, with additional focused training when incidents occur or when new glass types or procedures are introduced. Use real examples from your establishment to make training relevant — discuss what happened, why it happened, and how the incident could have been prevented. Depersonalize these discussions to focus on system improvements rather than blaming individuals.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Incident Reporting and Investigation
subsections.content:
Establish a clear, non-punitive system for reporting all glass-related incidents and near-misses. Staff must feel comfortable reporting broken glass, injuries, and 'close calls' without fear of blame. Each incident should trigger a brief investigation: What happened? What were the contributing factors? What can we change to prevent recurrence?

Track incident data over time to identify patterns. A sudden increase in breakage might indicate a problem with a particular glassware supplier, a busy period where staff are rushed, or a training need for specific individuals. Use this data to drive continuous improvement in your glass safety program.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Personal Protective Equipment
subsections.content:
For certain tasks involving higher glass injury risk — such as collecting glasses from outdoor areas where broken glass may be hidden, or dealing with particularly hazardous cleanups — consider providing cut-resistant gloves. These gloves must meet appropriate safety standards (EN 388 with good cut resistance rating) and be maintained in good condition. However, gloves should never substitute for proper handling techniques — they are a supplementary control measure, not the primary one.

Ensure that all staff know the location of first aid supplies for treating glass cuts. Every bar area should have immediate access to clean running water, antiseptic, adhesive plasters (preferably blue, waterproof plasters that are easily visible if lost), and sterile gauze for larger cuts. Staff should be trained in basic first aid response to glass cuts and know when a cut requires professional medical attention.

checklists.title: Pre-Service Glass Safety Checklist
items: All glassware has been visually inspected for chips, cracks, and cloudiness
Rim inspection has been conducted on all glasses by running finger around the rim
Any damaged glassware has been removed from service and placed in broken glass disposal
Clean, designated ice scoops are available at all ice stations
Broken glass disposal containers are empty and clearly labeled
Glass cleanup kit (stiff brush, dustpan, damp cloths) is readily accessible
First aid supplies for glass cuts are stocked and accessible
All bar staff have been briefed on glass safety procedures for the shift
Storage areas are organized with glassware stable and secure
Warning signs or barriers for any recent breakage areas are in place if needed

checklists.title: Broken Glass Response Checklist
items: Area has been secured and customers/staff alerted by calling 'broken glass'
Any injured persons have been attended to and first aid administered
Proper cleanup tools have been gathered — brush, dustpan, damp cloths
Large fragments have been collected using dustpan, not bare hands
Small fragments have been swept with stiff brush into dustpan
Smallest fragments and glass dust have been collected with damp cloths
Area has been wiped again with fresh damp cloth to capture final particles
Floor has been mopped if on hard surface, or vacuumed if on carpet
All broken glass has been disposed of in designated broken glass container
Area has been inspected in good light from multiple angles before declaring clean
Incident has been logged with details of what broke, where, and how
Any contaminated food or drink items have been identified and discarded

checklists.title: Weekly Glass Safety Audit
items: Review glass breakage incidents from the past week
Analyze any patterns in breakage by location, time, or staff member
Inspect glassware inventory for damaged items that escaped daily inspection
Check condition of ice scoops and replace any that are damaged
Verify that broken glass disposal containers are being used correctly
Review first aid records for any glass-related injuries
Assess adequacy of glass cleanup supplies and restock as needed
Conduct brief refresher training with staff if any recurring issues identified
Check glassware storage areas for stability and appropriate organization
Verify that all staff are aware of and following glass safety procedures

bestPractices: Develop a pre-service ritual of running your finger around the rim of every glass — this habit becomes automatic and catches chips before they reach customers
Store ice scoops with the handle up and the scoop portion elevated out of the ice to prevent contamination and accidental burial
Use trays for carrying multiple glasses whenever possible rather than hand-carrying, which significantly reduces breakage
Establish a 'broken glass station' with all cleanup supplies in one accessible location so staff don't waste time searching during an incident
Consider investing in tempered glassware for high-volume service areas where breakage rates are highest
Implement a glass replacement budget line item and replace glasses proactively before they become dangerously damaged
Conduct monthly glass safety toolbox talks that take just 5 minutes but keep awareness high
Recognize and praise staff who demonstrate excellent glass safety practices to reinforce positive behavior

glossary.Tempered Glass: Glass that has been heat-treated to increase its strength and change its breakage pattern — tempered glass shatters into small granular pieces rather than large dangerous shards
glossary.Stemware: Drinking glasses with a bowl, stem, and base (such as wine glasses and champagne flutes) that require specific handling techniques to prevent stem breakage
glossary.Rim Chip: A small piece broken from the drinking edge of a glass that creates a sharp edge hazardous to customers' lips and mouth
glossary.Star Crack: A pattern of radiating cracks typically found in the base of a glass, indicating stress damage that may cause sudden failure
glossary.Stress Fracture: A crack in glass caused by thermal shock, impact, or twisting stress that weakens the glass structure
glossary.Cross-Contamination: In glass safety context, the transfer of glass fragments to areas or items beyond the initial breakage site, potentially contaminating food, drink, or other clean glassware
glossary.EN Standards: European Norm (EN) standards that specify safety and quality requirements for various products including glassware
glossary.Cut-Resistant Gloves: Protective gloves made from materials like Kevlar or steel mesh that provide resistance to cuts from sharp objects while allowing manual dexterity
glossary.Ice Scoop: A dedicated utensil with a handle, made of metal or food-safe plastic, used exclusively for transferring ice to prevent glass contamination
glossary.Broken Glass Container: A separate, clearly marked, puncture-resistant container designated specifically for disposal of broken glass to prevent injury to waste handlers
